Award.AwardTitle: NUE: Development of a Computational Curriculum for Undergraduates in NanoTechnology and NanoEngineering (NanoCompute)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this proposal, NUE: Development of a Computational Curriculum for Undergraduates in NanoTechnology and NanoEngineering (NanoCompute)at the University of California San Diego (UCSD), under the direction of Dr. Andrea Tao, will be to develop a new focus within the nanoengineering curriculum that emphasizes computation, simulation, and modeling. Computation-based learning methods will be integrated into new and existing undergraduate courses in the NanoEngineering (NE) Department, starting with first-year engineering courses and culminating in a two-quarter capstone senior design course. The proposed NanoCompute curriculum is a novel approach to undergraduate education in nanotechnology because it will provide formal hands-on training in computation approaches that is fully integrated with the NE Department's four-year Bachelor of Science curriculum.

The curriculum for NanoCompute is expected to impact all undergraduates majoring in nanoengineering and chemical engineering at UCSD, which is estimated at 1000+ students over the next two years. NanoCompute will be implemented to meet the Engineering Science Program requirements as laid out by the Accreditation Board for Engineering Technology, and this proposal will develop new pedagogy in computational nanoengineering that we expect to impact all future degree programs in this area. There are currently no established criteria for accredited degree programs in nanoengineering or nanotechnology. To enable impact on a national level, the project team will develop a modular course format that is readily implemented by other academic institutions. As part of NanoCompute, there will be a focus on recruiting and retaining undergraduate students in the NE Department from underrepresented and underprivileged groups. The educational efforts of this proposal will seek to develop human resources in advanced technology, which is vital to economic growth in California and the U.S. as a whole.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit developed by this award is the development of a focused computation, modeling, and simulation (CSM) curriculum for undergraduates that teaches an in-depth understanding of the core concepts underlying nanomaterials and nanoscale processes from a computational perspective. Undergraduate training has included the practice and knowledge of computational techniques in both classroom, laboratory, and research-based learning environments.

The broader impacts stemming from this award is in the development of human resources that will be necessary for the next generation workforce in nanotechnology. The curriculum and knowledge generated through the NanoCompute program has enabled undergraduates to develop the computational, simulations and modeling skillsets needed for this fast-growing interdisciplinary field with broad applications in medicine, energy, aerospace, and national defense.

Outcomes: The NanoCompute Program has directly impacted over 300 unique students within the Nanoengineering major at UC San Diego, and will continue to impact students beyond the lifetime of the award through major improvements to the integrated computational and experimental infrastructure of the Nanoengineering undergraduate labs. This award has led to the creation of two new classes that will be institutionalized within the NANO undergraduate degree program, the further development of four existing courses, and the creation and implementation of three new senior design lab modules focused on CSM techniques. In addition, the NANO undergraduate curriculum has adopted computational modeling as one of five techniques, skills, and modern engineering tools that are considered necessary for modern nanoengineering practice. Direct assessments of whether Nanoengineering graduates are able to use computation modeling for engineering analysis, design, or experimental work will be carried out on an annual basis.
